title: 103_hr2684
content:
The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Improvement Act of 1993 amends the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act to include cooperative programs with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. It also addresses the membership of the Board of Directors of the Foundation. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to require consultation with the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere before appointing any Director of the Board. The Board is also expanded from nine to fifteen members. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to expand the Board of Directors from nine to fifteen members. The Secretary of the Interior will appoint additional members within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, with specified terms of 2, 4, or 6 years. The Board of Directors of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation will be expanded from nine to fifteen members, with the Secretary of the Interior appointing additional members within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Board's authority is not affected by any delays in appointing new members. SEC. 104 of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to increase the authorized funding to $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1994-1998. This additional authorization is separate from any other federal funding available to the Foundation. SEC. 105. CONVEYANCE OF SENECAVILLE NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY. The Secretary of the Interior shall convey the Senecaville National Fish Hatchery to Ohio, including all property and interests, for use by the Ohio Department of Natural Resources. Reversion to the United States will occur if the property is not used for the Ohio fishery resources management program. The property and interests must be used for the Ohio fishery resources management program to prevent reversion to the United States. Establishment of the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas under the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1993. The Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center at the Port of Brownsville, Texas, established under the Brownsville Wetlands Policy Act of 1993, focuses on protecting, restoring, and maintaining the Lagoon Ecosystems of the Western Gulf of Mexico Region. It is operated by the Port of Brownsville with programs administered by the University of Texas at Brownsville. The Center in the Western Gulf of Mexico Region is governed by a Board of Directors cochaired by the Port of Brownsville, University of Texas at Brownsville, and a designee of the Fish and Wildlife Service. The Board prepares an annual report covering programs, projects, activities, and budget for submission to Congress. The Board of Directors of the Center in the Western Gulf of Mexico Region must provide annual reports on the budget and funding sources. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit reports to Congress on the Center's operations. The Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service can provide grants to the Center for its activities. The Director may also lease wetlands property from the Port of Brownsville for the Center's use. The lease terms will be negotiated and can be terminated by the Director. Other requirements may apply. The University of Texas at Brownsville and the Port of Brownsville must provide space and resources for the Center as conditions for receiving assistance. The Port of Brownsville must make up to 7,000 acres of Port Property available for the Center's programs. The Board of Directors must report annually on whether these conditions have been met. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations totaling $13,000,000 for fiscal years 1994-1997 is granted to the Director of the US Fish and Wildlife Service for grants to the Center. Funds cannot be used to relocate operations from Corpus Christi to Brownsville Wetlands Policy Center. TITLE III--WALTER B. JONES CENTER FOR THE SOUNDS AT THE POCOSIN LAKES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE

SEC. 301. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that the Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge in northeastern North Carolina lacks an educational center for visitors. A partnership has been proposed to establish the Center for the Sounds, which would bring economic benefits to Tyrrell County and the town of Columbia. The Federal Government designated the Albemarle-Pamlico estuary system as an estuary of national concern. Walter B. Jones supported the establishment and expansion of National Wildlife Refuges in eastern North Carolina, including the Alligator River and Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuges. Walter B. Jones played a significant role in increasing refuge acreage in eastern North Carolina, ensuring protection for wildlife habitat and public recreation. He also supported the reintroduction of endangered red wolves at Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge, contributing to the successful effort to reintroduce predators into their former habitat. Additionally, Jones dedicated much of his congressional career to the conservation of fish and wildlife, benefiting both the Nation and the people of North Carolina. Walter B. Jones played a significant role in increasing refuge acreage in eastern North Carolina and supported the reintroduction of endangered red wolves at Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge. He should be honored by having the Center for the Sounds at the Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge System named after him for his conservation efforts. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to construct and operate the "Walter B. Jones Center for the Sounds" at the Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge in North Carolina. The facility aims to provide public opportunities for studying natural history, offering environmental educational programs, fostering awareness of wildlife ecosystems, and providing office space for refuge activities. The Secretary of the Interior will ensure that the design, size, and location of the facility are in line with the area's cultural and natural history. Non-Federal sources can contribute funds for operating and maintaining the facility. A report on progress in designing and constructing the facility, as well as efforts to obtain contributions, must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 3, 1993. Clerk: DONNALD K. ANDERSON.
